Project Title: Elucidating novel molecular mechanisms of irisin-mediated effects via integrin

Project Title: Fatal Overdose Review Teams - Research to Enhance Surveillance Systems (FORTRESS)
Public Health Relevance:
PROJECT NARRATIVE
The continued rise in overdose rates and sheer number of preventable overdose deaths suggest a need to
improve practices of widely-established overdose fatality review (OFR) teams by shifting OFRs away from case
review and toward using timely, population-level data to better inform their recommendations and actions. Thus,
we will provide OFRs with a real time overdose-related dashboard and data-driven decision making training.
We anticipate that our proposed intervention will lead to better quality, actionable OFR recommendations;
increased OFR actions to implement evidence-based overdose strategies based on dashboard data; and long
term reductions in both fatal and nonfatal overdoses.

Project Title: Optimizing pain-related outcomes following orthopedic trauma: testing novel risk factors and determining the feasibility of a new pain psychology intervention
Public Health Relevance:
PROJECT NARRATIVE
Orthopedic trauma is common and often associated with profound pain and psychological distress that can
persist for years following injury and relate to long-term disability. To promote adaptive recovery, there is an
urgent need to elucidate factors that relate to pain and distress following orthopedic trauma and to develop
targeted psychological interventions that address these potentially disabling symptoms. This project will take
initial steps towards addressing this gap and will lay the groundwork for an independent research program that
will harness pain pathophysiology and affective science to promote adaptive recovery following orthopedic
trauma.

Project Title: Characterizing the Relationship between Uterine Activity and Placental Function Across Pregnancy with MRI
Public Health Relevance:
PROJECT NARRATIVE
While normally growing fetuses with healthy placentas have enough placental reserve capacity that Braxton
Hicks contractions do not significantly affect necessary placental oxygen transport, in dysfunctional placentas
with poor reserve these events may lead to hypoxic stress. There is a lack of information regarding the effect of
Braxton Hicks contractions in human pregnancies and whether these findings may provide information that will
inform development of future tests to identify fetuses at risk for adverse outcomes during delivery mediated by
placental dysfunction. We propose to characterize Braxton Hicks contractions across gestation, to analyze
spatio-temporal changes in placental oxygenation during these contractions and to monitor the effect of
placental oxygenation changes on fetal movement and fetal organ oxygenation via MRI.

providers. We will measure the impact of different providers on health outcomes and then use detailed data on

Project Title: Integrated functional and structural analysis of an entire column in mouse primary visual cortex
Public Health Relevance:
PROJECT NARRATIVE
The anatomical and structural organization of a healthy brain regulates its computation, and the assessment of
this regulation could reveal the underlying basis of numerous neurological and psychiatric disorders. In this
project, we propose to archive and analyze the largest calcium imaging dataset collected to date from an entire
column in the mouse primary visual cortex. We aim to use this data, along with the electron microscopy
reconstructions of neurons in V1, to design a novel topologically-plausible model of neurons in order to
understand how neural structure constrains its function.

Public Health Relevance:

and intervention of cardiovascular disease, especially when patients are asymptomatic. Our technology, which
innovatively combines material engineering to tune electro-optical properties of chalcogenide alloys, detector
structure design, and artificial intelligence-guided image processing, brings much-needed quantitative

chest x-rays and will have immense impact on proactive healthcare, improving the clinical outcomes of patients,
and reducing the number of deaths associated with cardiovascular disease.

Project Title: 2/4 Deciphering Mechanisms of ECT Outcomes and Adverse Effects (DECODE)
Public Health Relevance:
Electroconvulsive therapy (ECT) is the most effective therapy for adults with major depression; however, some
patients fail to respond despite an adequate trial, and ECT can produce negative cognitive effects. In this revised
four site, prospective study we propose the first investigation of ECT outcome integrating multiple types of data
including clinical and cognitive measures, whole-brain neuroimaging, EEG, and E-field modeling to establish the
mechanisms underlying ECT-induced antidepressant response (response biomarkers) and negative cognitive
effects (safety biomarkers). Using this approach in patients with major depressive disorder (n = 230), we will
confirm the “sweet spot” of ECT dosing in order to maximize antidepressant benefit and cognitive safety.

Project Title: Biomarkers of Developmental Language Disorder and Their Relationship to Language Impairment
Public Health Relevance:
Projective Narrative
Developmental Language Disorder (DLD) is a pervasive language disorder that can affect both comprehension
and production of spoken, written and signed language, yet little is understood about the underlying neurological
basis for DLD. The goal of this proposal is to explore the relationship between language impairment and two
measures of brain function, cerebral blood flow and functional connectivity, in children with DLD. By exploring
underlying measures of brain function in DLD, we can begin to identify biomarkers of language impairment that
may lay the groundwork for aiding in the identification and treatment of the disorder.

Project Title: Using mouse pain scales to discover unusual pain sensitivity and new pain targets
Public Health Relevance:
Project Narrative
The proposed research is relevant to public health because it will identify genetically diverse
mouse lines with heightened or reduced pain sensitivity that can be used for finding new targets
to treat chronic pain. In this project we will also seek to identify new pain targets which come
directly from studies sequencing pain neurons in humans. The project is relevant to the mission
of NIH because of its potential to mirror the genetic diversity to pain sensation observed in humans

Project Title: Immuno-stromal axes regulate fibroblast heterogeneity in tissue fibrosis and regeneration

health and regenerative medicine-based therapies, while a promising strategy, still face two critical obstacles:
chronic inflammation and fibrosis. We pose an innovative hypothesis whereby immuno-stromal signaling axes
and fibroblast heterogeneity link together inflammation and disrupted mechanotransduction, bridging a critical
gap in our understanding of tissue fibrosis and regeneration. Developing a better understanding of immuno-
stromal crosstalk will help elucidate disease pathogenesis, new candidates for biomarkers, and targets for
therapeutic interventions.

According to the American Sleep Association, 50-70 million US adults have a sleep disorder,
insomnia being the most common specific sleep disorder with 30% of adults reporting short term
issues and 10% reporting chronic insomnia. Meanwhile, 37.9% US adults reported unintentionally
falling asleep during the day at least once in the preceding month, while 4.7% reported nodding

driving is responsible for 1,550 fatalities and 40,000 nonfatal injuries annually in the US, this

estimated in the general population to range between 3% and 17%, lacks an effective treatment as
most of the available treatments have only moderate efficacy and present significant side effects

HT7R agonists which have been demonstrated to have therapeutic advantages for treating certain
sleep disorders and neuropathic pain and are proposed in this application, are urgently needed.

Project Title: Calcium Channels in Glioblastoma
Public Health Relevance:
NARRATIVE
Glioblastoma is the most common malignant brain tumor and one of the deadliest human cancers. We found
that calcium channels, known as T-Type calcium channels, are upregulated in glioblastoma and drive
malignancy. We propose to study what T-Type calcium channels do in glioblastoma, how they work, how they
interact with the surrounding brain, and if we can target them for therapy using a repurposed FDA approved
drug and other therapeutic strategies. If successful, these studies will improve our understanding of the
molecular mechanisms of glioblastoma and lead to the development of new and more efficient therapies.

Project Title: Discovery and manipulation of transcription factors to restore long term stem cell repopulation in aged bone-marrow
Public Health Relevance:
Project Narrative
The complex biology of aging, characterized by a progressive loss of cellular and physiological function, is
particularly evident in hematopoietic stem cells (HSCs) where aging results in a reduced capacity to self-renew
and differentiate into lymphoid lineages. We propose a two-pronged approach for reversing HSC aging via
cellular reprogramming, involving 1) profiling molecular signatures of aging in HSCs at single cell resolution to
both develop metrics for aging and nominate transcription factors (TFs) involved in aging and self-renewal and
2) screening of TFs nominated by single-cell RNA-sequencing for restoration of HSC quiescence, self-renewal,
lymphoid/myeloid balance, and systemic effects in an in vivo mouse aging model. Novel TFs will be characterized
for their mechanism in renewing HSCs and restoring other downstream lineages in the bone marrow, and the

Bronchopulmunary Dysplasia (BPD) is a disease of pre-term infants whose lungs are injured upon exposure to
excess oxygen from ventilators, impairing effective gas exchange in the lungs. Ayuvis Research is developing a

prophylactic treatment for BPD and treatment for other life-threatening lung conditions.

Project Title: The Role of the Aging Brain-Heart-Immune Axis in Postoperative Delirium
Public Health Relevance:
RELEVANCE STATEMENT
Vagal tone, which naturally decreases with advancing age, allows the brain to control systemic inflammation,
via the brain-heart-immune axis. Even though excessive postoperative inflammation is hypothesized the cause
delirium in older adults and to potentiate Alzheimer’s disease and related dementias via neuronal injury, the
role of the brain-heart-immune axis in postoperative delirium remains unexplored. This study aims to establish
the role of the vagus nerve-mediated brain-heart-immune axis in postoperative delirium pathogenesis and,
thus, to facilitate the development of interventions to enhance preoperative vagal tone, to improve cognitive
outcomes after surgery, and to reduce the risk of Alzheimer’s Disease and related dementias in the nearly 20
million older Americans who undergo surgery annually.

Project Title: Mathematical Models of Tau-PET Measures and Cognitive Decline in Alzheimer’s Disease Across the Lifespan

I propose a biologically motivated, mathematical modeling approach to understand how neuroimaging and
other biomarkers can be used to better understand Alzheimer’s disease biology. I plan to fit mechanistic
models to data from 3 cohorts across the age span of Alzheimer’s disease onset: Longitudinal Early Onset
Alzheimer’s Disease Study (LEADS) (ages 40-64), Alzheimer’s Disease Neuroimaging Initiative (ADNI) cohort

understanding of the age-specific pathophysiology of Alzheimer’s disease, determining the precise relationship
between tau and cognition, with the ultimate goal of guiding therapeutic development and trials for Alzheimer’s
treatment.

Project Title: Virtual Activities of Living for Occupational Rehabilitation
Public Health Relevance:
PROJECT NARRATIVE
The proposed VALOR system consists of mobile virtual world software that enables functional practice of
immersive ADLs and IADLs for upper extremity (UE) stroke rehabilitation using a low-cost, untethered,
standalone VR headset with computer vision-based, markerless hand tracking. The proposed SBIR Phase I
research addresses important public health concerns by: (1) supporting telehealth delivery to improve patient
safety and increase access to remote and underserved areas; (2) providing low-cost access to evidence-based
care by marrying consumer hardware with advanced healthcare software; (3) improving stroke outcomes in UE
function by enabling increased frequency and intensity of practice; (4) promoting functional recovery through
combined physical practice and mental imagery; and (5) providing validated tracking mechanisms for patient
activity, functional status, and progress.

Project Title: Modernization of Salk's ABSL2 Facilities Through the Incorporation of Ventilated Caging
Public Health Relevance:
PROJECT NARRATIVE
The Salk Institute’s mouse Animal Biosafety Level 2 (ABSL2) suite within its Conventional Animal Research
Facility is at capacity and its use of static caging results in operational inefficiencies and undue animal stress
that can affect experimental outcomes. We propose to modernize this facility by renovating the floor plan and
installing racks of individually ventilated cages, thereby doubling cage capacity to enable the development and
expansion of ABSL2 research efforts at Salk. Further, improved housing conditions will enhance the rigor and
reproducibility of experiments conducted within this facility, providing tremendous benefit to the wide range of
research programs (e.g., infectious disease, neuroscience, and cancer) and faculty (33 of Salk’s 54 faculty
conduct ABSL2 work in mice) that take advantage of this critical shared resource.

Project Title: Reducing Disparities in Pediatric Diabetes: Building the Evidence Base to Inform Effective Diabetes Technology Interventions in Underrepresented Minorities
Public Health Relevance:
PROJECT NARRATIVE
 Youth from low socioeconomic groups are at a systematic disadvantage in the provision of diabetes care,
particularly diabetes technology which is associated with improvement in diabetes-specific outcomes. Thus, we
urgently need studies to understand and ameliorate the persistent worsening of disparities of diabetes
management and outcomes in youth from low socioeconomic backgrounds. This proposed research will (1)
improve representation of diverse youth in the literature, (2) address the gap in knowledge of barriers and
promoters in publicly insured youth, and (3) identify and address factors of worsening disparity in diabetes
technology.

Project Title: Effects of ketamine on tobacco use disorder - Resubmission
Public Health Relevance:
PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE
Cigarette smoking is a leading cause of death and disability in the United States and there is an ongoing need
for a greater diversity of treatment options. Increasingly, evidence implicates the glutamatergic system in the
addictive effects of nicotine, and ketamine, a glutamatergic receptor antagonist, has shown promise in treating
substance use disorders. This proposal will fill a gap in knowledge on the immediate and delayed effects of
ketamine on tobacco addiction, and is the first step towards a new pharmacotherapy option for tobacco use
disorder.

Project Title: Health-seeking Behaviors in Formerly Incarcerated Black Men
Public Health Relevance:
PROJECT NARRATIVE
This proposed study addresses NINR’s Notice of Special Interest in the priority areas of social determinants of
health, health disparities, and health equity because of the disparate impact of incarceration on Black men and
the negative health outcomes associated with incarceration history, including increased mental health
symptom severity and diminished health-related quality of life. Little is known about how formerly incarcerated
Black men recognize and address their health concerns through health-seeking behaviors and engagement in
mental health care. With an enhanced understanding of how incarceration influences mental health symptom
severity, health-related quality of life, health-seeking behaviors, and engagement in mental health care, we will
be better positioned to develop targeted interventions to promote health-seeking behaviors, minimize barriers
to care, and improve health outcomes.

Project Title: Scaling Up Research Ethics and Research Integrity (SURER) Project
Public Health Relevance:
Scaling Up Research Ethics and Research Integrity (SURER) Project
Project narrative
 With increasing number and scope of research projects, the University of Maryland School of Medicine,
Center for Bioethics and Research and University of Ibadan, Nigeria identified need to build capacity for
mentored Responsible Conduct of Research (RCR), research/scientific integrity (RSI), Conflict of Interest (CoI),
Diversity, Equity, and Inclusion (DEI), Safe Working Environment and Sexual Harassment training to strengthen
research environment in Nigeria. We engage our successful training resources, technologies, and models to
create new institutional resources and infrastructure, conduct advocacy, build public and professional
awareness, implement training and innovative e-mentoring for RCR, RSI, CoI, DEI, Safe Working Environment
and Sexual Harassment in sixteen Nigerian universities. We use the experiences and expectations of our
trainees and use these to create a Learning Educational Program (LEP) with regular adjustments and updates
to our curriculum contents and training examples.

Project Title: Simulation for Attending Obstetricians to Improve Technical Skills for Managing Postpartum Hemorrhage
Public Health Relevance:
Simulation is a promising solution to improve the technical skills of obstetricians for managing postpartum
hemorrhage (PPH), a rare but potentially life-threatening birth complication that disproportionately impacts
underserved women in the U.S. We propose a staged, multicenter study to trial three innovations to overcome
common obstacles to widespread implementation: a novel, affordable medium-fidelity simulator; remote
synchronous mentoring; and asynchronous mentoring. If successful, results will inform best practices, advance
education and training standards, and enable nationwide dissemination, including in low-resource settings.

Project Title: Probing conformational changes by protein surface azidation
Public Health Relevance:
PROJECT NARRATIVE
Using azide-containing hypervalent iodine reagents, we have developed a novel chemoproteomic
platform termed Protein Surface Azidation Mass Spectrometry (ProSurA-MS) that detects
conformational changes on protein surface with unbiased chemoselectivity. Combined with
bioorthogonal chemistry, ProSurA-MS effectively mapped dynamics of purified proteins upon
denaturation, protein-small molecule interaction, and protein-protein interaction, conformational
changes of a zinc-binding protein in whole cell lysate upon zinc depletion, and measured
proteome-wide azidation in live cells, thus potentiating the characterization of protein dynamics in
complex biological environments. The herein proposed studies will enable characterization of
dynamic changes in protein conformation induced by post-translational modifications and metal
binding, basic understanding of the chemical mechanism behind the ProSurA reaction and
development of second generation reagents with greater azidation yield and surface coverage,
and investigation of protein interaction networks via unbiased crosslinking.

Project Title: Overcoming the Multiple Scattering Limit in Optical Coherence Tomography
Public Health Relevance:
NARRATIVE
 The goal of this research program is to overcome the multiple scattering limit in optical coherence
tomography, and thereby address one of the grand challenges in the field of optical microscopy. We will
synergistically combine the advantages of a long-wavelength spectral-domain OCT system with adaptive optics,
and the principle behind the highly promising coherent accumulation of single scattering method. We propose to
demonstrate the deepest OCT imaging to date, in both human skin and mouse brain tissues, which is significant
from the perspective of both fundamental imaging science as well as the biomedical applications of OCT.

Project Title: Assessing the Long-term Impact of COVID-induced Telemedicine Expansion on Dementia Care
Public Health Relevance:
PROJECT NARRATIVE
A dramatic long-term effect of the COVID-19 pandemic is the expanded role of telemedicine integrated into
primary care, which is particularly significant for the more than 5 million people with dementia (PWD) and their
caregivers given the multi-faceted dimensions of clinical, social, and behavioral assessment and care for
dementia in the primary care setting. Drawing on data from two diverse health systems, UCSF Health and Kaiser
Permanente Northern CA, this project will study the implications of the COVID-induced expansion of
telemedicine across varied dimensions for PWD including equity of use, timeliness of care, and subsequent
near-term utilization. These findings, alongside insights from the broader literature, will be used to identify
strategies to tailor telemedicine use in primary care to better meet the needs of PWD.

Project Title: Motion and distortion robust diffusion weighted imaging sequences for pediatric patients
Public Health Relevance:
Project Narrative
Epilepsy surgery can result in seizure freedom or a marked reduction in seizures in approximately two-thirds of
children with intractable seizures who have been carefully selected, with minimal adverse functional loss.
Diffusion weighted magnetic resonance imaging (DW-MRI) is an important non-invasive tool that allows the
neurosurgeon to precisely map regions of the brain supporting critical functions that should be preserved;
however, excessive head motion can lead to mis-identification of these regions, with direct implications for
treatment. The proposed project, “Motion and distortion robust diffusion weighted imaging sequences for
pediatric patients” promises to deliver a highly innovative imaging method capable of producing high-quality
connectivity maps in the presence of uncontrolled head motion by tracking the position of the head and
updating the acquisition in real-time.

The brain has evolved the capacity to plan behavior multiple steps into the future by predicting the
consequences of alternative actions based on prior knowledge of the environment – a cognitive mechanism
known as multi-step planning. The proposed work will combine cellular-resolution calcium imaging and
chemogenetic inactivation with cutting-edge behavioral techniques to determine the role of the retrosplenial
cortex (RSC) in multi-step planning. The results from this work will advance our understanding of the neural
implementation of planning and inform future translational research on the disruption of action evaluation,
prospection, and goal-directed behavior in many psychiatric disorders.

and escape threats; however severe or chronic activation of this response can lead to diabetes. This project

identified in patients and loss-of-function studies in our animal model for post-infectious BGE. The study
represents a proof-of-concept to develop a translational platform for understanding how genetic factors in
combination with infectious agents (i.e. gene x environment interactions) cause an aberrant immune response
that targets the brain in post-infectious BGE.

Project Title: Controlling renal oxidative stress in CKD via targeting FGF23 bioactivity
Public Health Relevance:
Project Narrative
Chronic kidney disease (CKD), which affects 37 million Americans, progresses with the loss of important proteins
such as Klotho, leading to severe endocrine disease, as well as increased renal oxidative stress that further
damages the kidneys. In this career development proposal, I will enhance my computational skills to identify how

the molecular level. These studies will provide the backdrop for key career development as well as help to identify
new pathways regulated by Klotho and FGF23 that may slow CKD progression, and potentially uncover novel
therapeutic targets.

Project Title: Smartphone-based wound infection screener and care recommender by combining thermal images and photographs using deep learning methods
Public Health Relevance:
I. Project Narrative: Smartphone-based wound infection risk screener and care recommender
by combining thermal images and photographs using deep learning methods.
There is currently no method to diagnose infections in undebrided wounds at the Point of Care (POC) (e.g., in
patients’ homes by visiting nurses), resulting in unnecessary referrals to wound clinics and increasing the time
to treatment of infections and the likelihood of eventual amputation. To facilitate early and accurate detection of
infected wounds at the POC, we propose a smartphone-based screener that jointly analyzes a combination of
photographs and a thermal image of a wound using deep learning methods. Our proposed system will detect
infections in both debrided and undebrided wounds and recommend evidence-based best care and when to
refer infected wounds to experts, standardizing the quality of care provided by non-expert wound caregivers.

Project Title: Linking trigeminal and visual sensitivity in migraine

touch (allodynia) and light (photophobia). In this project we will measure the blink reflex

hypothesis that a common change in the trigeminal system of the brainstem is at work in
sensory alteration in migraine.

Project Title: Respiratory Effects, Metal and Aldehyde exposure from e-cigarette use in young adults (REMA)
Public Health Relevance:
PROJECT NARRATIVE
Electronic cigarette (e-cig) use among adults remains the highest among those aged 18-24 years, despite critical
knowledge gaps on chemical exposure, toxicity and potential health effects. New and emerging e-cig devices,
such as disposable PODs, are of particular concern as it is currently unknown whether they emit toxic metals
and aldehydes, and whether these devices have potential respiratory and inflammatory effects with use. By
evaluating device characteristics and user vaping regimen in association with toxic metal and aldehyde exposure

Project Title: The role of state Medicaid policies in treatment for opioid use disorder in the criminal justice population: Evidence from the Treatment Episode Datasets
Public Health Relevance:
PROJECT NARRATIVE
Individuals involved in the criminal justice system have higher rates of opioid use disorder (OUD) and are less
likely to receive OUD treatment, including medications for opioid use disorder (MOUDs). The majority of
incarcerated individuals are low-income and uninsured and are, therefore, likely Medicaid eligible, which raises
important questions about the role of Medicaid policy in access to treatment for criminal justice involved
individuals. Using a quasi-experimental approach and data from the Treatment Episode Datasets from 2000-
2017, this study will examine the effects of state Medicaid policies on OUD treatment outcomes for individuals
referred to treatment by the criminal justice system and will provide important and timely information to support
evidence-based policy- and decision-making.

Project Title: Enabling precise cell-type-specific dissection of orientation and memory circuits in retrosplenial cortex

Damage to a brain region called the retrosplenial cortex leads to pronounced spatial disorientation as
well as severe memory deficits, but the retrosplenial cells, circuits, and computations supporting
healthy orientation and memory processing remain poorly understood. We have identified a unique,
small, excitable neuronal subtype within the retrosplenial cortex that is ideally positioned to support its
spatial orientation and memory functions. Here, we create novel electrodes and build comprehensive
transcriptomic maps to enable the future cell-type-specific dissection of orientation and memory
circuits within the retrosplenial cortex.

Project Title: Circuit Mechanisms of Psilocybin Following Chronic Stress
Public Health Relevance:
PROJECT NARRATIVE 
Chronic stress plays a role in multiple neuropsychiatric disorders, many of which lack highly efficacious treatments. Project Title: Vascular contribution to white matter lesions and motor dysfunction in AD and ADRD
Public Health Relevance:
Many Alzheimer’s Disease (AD) patients exhibit signs of motor dysfunction and furthermore,
changes in motor function often precede other AD symptoms as well as correlate with increased
severity of dementia and mortality. Familial Danish Dementia (FDD) is an AD-like familial
dementia characterized by vascular amyloid deposits, white matter damage, and motor
dysfunction. Since the molecular mechanism underlying motor dysfunction in AD and FDD is
unclear, we would like to analyze postmortem brain tissues of AD patients who clinically
exhibited motor deficits in the early disease state and investigate the pathogenic mechanism of
motor dysfunction in rodent models of AD and FDD using biochemical, histological, and genetic
methods in addition to several advanced MRI techniques.

Project Title: An intervention to promote healthy relationships among transgender and gender expansive youth
Public Health Relevance:

Transgender and gender expansive (TGE) youth are at high risk of several sexual health outcomes that have
life-long impacts including sexually transmitted infections, early, unwanted pregnancies, and unwanted sexual
contact/intimate partner violence. TGE youth deserve effective, assets-based, gender affirming sex education,

Project Title: Network modulation to improve gene therapy in CLN3 disease

In two-thirds of lysosomal storage disorders (LSD), patients suffer neurologic symptoms that are not corrected
by most therapies, including gene replacement, especially if treatment is given after symptom onset. We
recently identified pathologic changes in hippocampal network dynamics that arise early in CLN3 disease, a
representative LSD, and the most common cause of pediatric dementia. The goal of this project is to
understand if early, progressive changes in network physiology in CLN3 disease will establish a point beyond
which gene therapy cannot restore function to a diseased neuronal circuit and to explore if modulating network
activity can modify the efficacy of gene replacement.

Project Title: Dysregulation of developing neural circuits during epileptogenesis
Public Health Relevance:
Narrative (Public Health Relevance)
A major focus of epilepsy research is to understand how brain cells and circuits become
permanently overexcited, such that they lead to the development of epilepsy and seizure
generation. This proposal focuses on the role of dividing brain cells that are born later in life,
and which their development can be altered by the experience of early seizures and thus
become mis-wired into the existing brain, facilitating the development of epilepsy and leading to
sensory processing disorders associated with several neurodevelopmental disorders.

prevent the development of epilepsy after a seizure, such as those occurring after traumatic
brain injury.

Project Title: Multifunctional Nanotechnology Platform for Triple Negative  Breast Cancer Treatment
Public Health Relevance:
Project Narrative: Triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC) accounts for approximately 15% of invasive breast
cancers; it is associated with aggressive tumor biology, poor prognosis, resistance, visceral metastases and
earlier disease recurrence and is more common in younger women than in older women and in African-American
and Hispanic women. To overcome the issues of toxicity, resistance and poor efficacy, we plan to develop
multifunctional targeted polymeric nanoparticles which will prove more effective with less toxicity than the current
standard of care therapies. A combination regimen using carboplatin and paclitaxel in the core of the
nanoparticles and highly selective anti-EGFR targeted agent (cetuximab) tagged on the surface of the
nanoparticles coupled with the power of nanotechnology will obviate suffering from toxicity, improve efficacy and
overcome resistance.

Project Title: Viral dynamics of rebound and reservoir HIV species in IPSC-derived myeloid cells
Public Health Relevance: Despite advances in antiretroviral therapy, suppression of HIV replication requires strict adherence and has toxicities. An eradicative cure requires elimination of virus reservoirs from all tissues, including lymph nodes, the gut and the central nervous system; therefore, a thorough understanding of HIV reservoirs that harbor intact and/or replication competent virus and give rise or support rebound viremia upon treatment interruption is paramount. Our novel approach using state-of-art technologies and models will define the role of microglia as a source for interferon-resistant rebound viruses in the correct cellular context and address a critical gap in our knowledge that is needed to eliminate HIV reservoir in the central nervous system.

Project Title: Molecular basis for adenosine A3 receptor agonists in the treatment of migraine
Public Health Relevance:
Project Narrative
Migraine is highly prevalent and debilitating, considered a major public health concern, and its underlying
pathobiology is not well understood. We propose to dissect a novel underlying mechanism, involving the
production of reactive nitroxidative species, and their downstream alterations to glutamatergic signaling and
neuroinflammatory mechanisms, which mediate nociceptive migraine-like responses. We will validate A3AR
agonists as a solution for the treatment of migraine, by modulating these underlying molecular mechanisms,
addressing this significant socioeconomic problem.

Project Title: Comprehensive functional phenotyping of trigeminal neurons innervating temporomandibular joint (TMJ) tissues in male female and aged mice primates and humans with and without TMJ disorders (TMJD)
Public Health Relevance:
Project Narrative
There is a critical gap in knowledge about innervation of the temporomandibular joint (TMJ) tissues. Here
we propose a study that will bridge this gap by comprehensively elucidating the functions, types,
neuroanatomical distributions, and plasticity of trigeminal neurons innervating muscle, tendon, and fascia
of the masseter and lateral pterygoid muscles, as well as the cartilage, joint capsule, and ligament
around the TMJ condyle. Our findings will fulfil all objectives of RE-JOIN program, lead to a better
mechanistic understanding of the development of temporomandibular joint disorder (TMJD) pain and
translate to improved prevention and management of TMJD pain.

establishing benchmarks for future development of therapeutics to treat disorders of the nervous system.
